featured.text: In the 1980s, proms were held in local churches for teenagers to attend.
Thomas Jefferson held the first inaugural open house in 1805; many of those who attended the swearing-in ceremony at the U.S. Capitol simply followed him home.
Everyone in the office must attend the meeting tomorrow.
Dooley keeps Peanuts company while the adults in the family attend to Grandfather.
Police and Glenn’s parade was attended by 500,000 -- a figure that appeared generously inflated.

other.text: Unable to attend music school, she began her career as a singer for church gatherings.
John's poor math score must have him a lot, because he is not attending the class any more.
Many scholars and experts from all over the world will be invited to attend this yearly ______ on drug control.
Many of his works—depictions of children at play and in school, farm girls attending to their work, hunters and their prey—have become classic images of nineteenth-century American life.
24 children can attend any family affair without seeing the adults enjoying their liquor.
Peter told Marie that he couldn't attend her birthday party because he had been engaged.

The 1962 celebration "was more enthusiastic -- a lot more people," said one spectator, who as a young newlywed attended Glenn’s first parade and came from her Brooklyn home again for Glenn’s second parade.
Steve has several meetings to attend every day; therefore, he has to work on a very _____ schedule.

definition.en_def: To be present at an event, meeting, or gathering.
definition.example: I will attend the conference next week.
